reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2017
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Wonderful collection of stories
reviews.reviewText: This is the first Sci fi anthology I have read and it won't be the last. I loved the diversity of stories and wonderful writing. A couple of weak stories but I enjoyed them all. Most are short enough to finish in a few minutes. Great for me lately habit of reading before sleep. Favorites were honey and death, the bridge across the mist. This was a steal at $2 as a bookbub selection. We'll worth it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2012
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Excellent Variety and Some Real Hits
reviews.reviewText: Whenever you get an anthology of short stories you're going to get some hits, some you can take or leave, and a few that you can't understand why they were included to begin with. This collection, for me, had many hits, a few I could take or leave, and no duds.The advantage to a big collection like this is that you get a wide variety of styles and subject matter. The anthology has both fantasy and science fiction stories, and these explore a lot of sub-genres and different takes on these fields. The drawback is that most of the stories are quite short, and just about the time you're really getting into them, they're over. This is a very different reading experience than reading even a short novel. If you picture the experience of this book as a buffet or a dim sum, you have the right metaphor: lots of small bites, nothing that gives you a full stomach on its own. I read this book at the rate of one story a day and chewed it up in about a month, which felt just right. I read several other books while reading this one, which you can get away with, because each short story requires only a small commitment to finish, and there are no continuing characters or plot lines to keep straight from day to day.In terms of quality, this is a big book (nearly 600 pages) chock full of strong stories that cut across many sub-genres. Whatever it is you like, there's almost guaranteed to be some of it here. In terms of value, there are about 30 stories herein. I'm not sure what that is in word count, but it's a great value for its buck. You can use this collection to find new authors, zeroing in on short works you really like and checking out that author's longer works to see if you like those, too. In terms of how it stacks up against other "Best of" anthologies, I would say it's stronger than Rich Horton's sci-fi and fantasy collection (fewer duds, no repeats) and not as strong as Gardner Dozois' best of sci-fi, which tends to be scarily good. I definitely recommend it for casual reading or to fit in with other works and to scan for new writers and old favorites.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars One of the best anthologies
reviews.reviewText: I read several SF yearly anthologies a year and this is one of the best. I'm a harsh critic but I know good writing.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2020
reviews.reviewText: Didn't like most of the stories. If these were the Best, Science Fiction is in trouble. The last story about Mars was good.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Lots of interesting stories
reviews.reviewText: Science fiction anthologies always seem to need a bit more editing, but the variety of stories makes up fo that. Sometimes a story seems to end too soon, and we wish for several hundred more words.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2012
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing and well written stories
reviews.reviewText: I love good SF short stories and this collection has some of the finest I've ever read. The other thing I really liked about this collection was how different they all were. Almost half the stories were written by woman showing the strong influence on SiFi they now have. I truly gobbled this book up reading one story after another. A great read!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2019
reviews.reviewText: Especially the last one. Lovely mix of ideas and concepts. Do enjoy this. Worth your time. I loved all of them.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2018
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A good year
reviews.reviewText: Some stories were fantastic, some were ho-hum. I loved Ken Liu, Stephen Baxter, Peter S. Beagle, Kid Johnson, An Owomoyela, K. J Parker. Others were just not my thing. But every volume is worth it. I'm just starting nine now and I find Strahan's collections to be the best I've read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 27, 2012
reviews.reviewText: I bought this book for my son as a Christmas present, and he was really pleased with it. Anthologies like this are a useful way of finding out about the work of writers you may not have encountered before, and my son has commented positively about some of the stories, so it's served its purpose well already and it's only 27 December!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 1, 2012
reviews.reviewTitle: Not one of the better anthologies
reviews.reviewText: A respectable showing by the more established writers is tempered by an uncharacteristically weak one from newer authors - which is a shame imo since it is always a pleasure to discover a new writer - but there are few here that i would be motivated to follow in future.Reading some parts of this felt more of a chore than a pleasure to be honest.
